abstract: Lindsey Hallen, 31-year-old emergency room nurse in Manhattan, is heading to West Africa to join the fight against Ebola as a volunteer with Boston-based organization Partners in Health.
headline: A Nurse Decides to Get Hands-On in the Ebola Zone
paragraph: While most accounts of American health workers have focused on the ones returning, Lindsey Hallen, an emergency room nurse in Manhattan, is heading to West Africa to fight an epidemic that has killed more than 8,000 people.
text: A Nurse Decides to Get Hands-On in the Ebola Zone While most accounts of American health workers have focused on the ones returning, Lindsey Hallen, an emergency room nurse in Manhattan, is heading to West Africa to fight an epidemic that has killed more than 8,000 people. Lindsey Hallen, 31-year-old emergency room nurse in Manhattan, is heading to West Africa to join the fight against Ebola as a volunteer with Boston-based organization Partners in Health.

headline: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARTIKAINEN, DR. A. HELEN. OF CHAPEL HILL, NC, AGE 98, DIED ON JANUARY 16, 2015 AT CAROL WOODS RETIREMENT COMMUNITY. BORN AND RAISED IN HARRISON, ME SHE WAS THE DAUGHTER OF THE LATE SYLVESTER AND EMMA MARTIKAINEN. SHE GRADUATED FROM BRIDGTON ACADEMY, AND RECEIVED HER B.A. DEGREE FROM BATES COLLEGE, AND RECEIVED POST GRADUATE DEGREES IN PUBLIC HEALTH FROM YALE AND HARVARD. DR. MARTIKAINEN SERVED AS HEALTH EDUCATION SPECIALIST WITH THE PUBLIC HEALTH SOCIETY HARTFORD, CT AND SEVERAL YEARS WITH UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE, WASHINGTON, DC. DURING SERVICE WITH USPHS, SHE WAS ASSIGNED TO OKLAHOMA, AND AN EXTENDED ASSIGNMENT AS ACTING DIRECTOR HEALTH EDUCATION WITH NORTH CAROLINA BOARD PUBLIC HEALTH, RALEIGH, NC. IN 1949, DR. MARTIKAINEN WAS APPOINTED FIRST CHIEF OF HEALTH EDUCATION, HEADQUARTERS, WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION (WHO), GENEVA, SWITZERLAND (1949, 1974). SHE ASSISTED NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS IN COUNTRIES WORLDWIDE. RETIREMENT IN CHAPEL HILL IN 1978, SHE VOLUNTEERED WITH N.C. DIVISION AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF UNIVERSITY WOMEN, UNITED NATIONS ASSOCIATION OF USA, N.C. COALITION OF AGING, WOMEN'S ISSUES, EPISCOPAL DIOCESE OF N.C. SHE WAS A MEMBER OF WOMEN'S FORUM OF N.C., BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR N.C. CENTER OF LAWS AFFECTING WOMEN, BOARD OF ORANGE COUNTY WOMEN'S CENTER, ADVISORY BOARD UNC SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH, NC ASSOCIATION OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND PUBLIC HEALTH ALUMNI OF HARVARD UNIVERSITY. AT CAROL WOODS, SHE SERVED AS CHAIR, RESIDENTS COMMITTEE FOR HEALTH; MEMBER OF RESIDENTS COUNCIL, CHAPEL OF CROSS, CENTER OF PUBLIC POLICY RESEARCH. HER AWARDS INCLUDE: HONORARY DOCTORATE DEGREES OF SCIENCE FROM BATES COLLEGE AND SMITH COLLEGE; INTERNATIONAL AWARD, AMERICAN PUBLIC HEALTH ASSOC.; ELIJAH BENJAMIN MAYS AWARD, BATES COLLEGE; WOMEN OF DISTINCTION AWARD, NC COUNCIL; SPECIAL MEDAL FROM NATIONAL ACADEMY OF MEDICINE, FRANCE; HONORARY TRUSTEE HALL OF FAME BRIDGTON ACADEMY; ELECTION TO PHI BETA KAPPA, BATES COLLEGE; DELTA OMEGA CHAPTER, YALE UNIVERSITY, LISTED IN WHO'S WHO: AMERICAN WOMEN, WORLD HEALTH CARE & MEDICINE. SHE WAS PREDECEASED BY BROTHERS, REINO J. MARTIKAINEN AND ERNEST W. MARTIKAINEN AND SISTER IRJA M. BOWNES. SHE IS SURVIVED BY A SISTER, SYLVIA M. MARTIN, SISTER, IN, LAW, MRS. ERNEST W. (PRISCILLA) MARTIKAINEN AND SEVERAL NIECES AND NEPHEWS. IN LIEU OF FLOWERS, MEMORIALS MADE TO: THE CHAPEL OF THE CROSS, 304 E. FRANKLIN ST., CHAPEL HILL, NC 27514. 1
paragraph: MARTIKAINEN--Dr. A. Helen. Of Chapel Hill, NC, age 98, died on January 16, 2015 at Carol Woods Retirement Community. Born and raised in Harrison, ME she was the daughter of the late Sylvester and Emma Martikainen. She graduated from Bridgton Academy, and received her B.A. degree from Bates College, and received post graduate degrees in public health from Yale and Harvard. Dr. Martikainen served as health education specialist with the Public Health Society Hartford, CT and several years with United States Public Health Service, Washington, DC. During service with USPHS, she was assigned to Oklahoma, and an extended assignment as Acting Director Health Education with North Carolina Board Public Health, Raleigh, NC. In 1949, Dr. Martikainen was appointed first Chief of Health Education, Headquarters, World Health Organization (WHO), Geneva, Switzerland (1949-1974). She assisted national health programs in countries worldwide. Retirement in Chapel Hill in 1978, she volunteered with N.C. Division American Association of University Women, United Nations Association of USA, N.C. Coalition of Aging, Women's Issues, Episcopal Diocese of N.C. She was a member of Women's Forum of N.C., Board of Directors for N.C. Center of Laws Affecting Women, Board of Orange County Women's Center, Advisory Board UNC School of Public Health, NC Association of Public Health and Public Health Alumni of Harvard University. At Carol Woods, she served as Chair, Residents Committee for Health; member of Residents Council, Chapel of Cross, Center of Public Policy Research. Her awards include: honorary doctorate degrees of science from Bates College and Smith College; International Award, American Public Health Assoc.; Elijah Benjamin Mays Award, Bates College; Women of Distinction Award, NC Council; special medal from National Academy of Medicine, France; Honorary Trustee Hall of Fame Bridgton Academy; election to Phi Beta Kappa, Bates College; Delta Omega Chapter, Yale University, Listed in WHO'S WHO: American Women, World Health Care & Medicine. She was predeceased by brothers, Reino J. Martikainen and Ernest W. Martikainen and sister Irja M. Bownes. She is survived by a sister, Sylvia M. Martin, sister-in-law, Mrs. Ernest W. (Priscilla) Martikainen and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, memorials made to: The Chapel of The Cross, 304 E. Franklin St., Chapel Hill, NC 27514. 1

abstract: World Health Organization says number of people becoming infected with Ebola virus in West Africa has fallen to lowest level in months; warns, however, that lack of funding and approach of rainy season may stymie efforts to control disease.
headline: Officials Say Ebola Cases Are Falling In West Africa
paragraph: Officials said that there had been a substantial reduction in new cases, but that dwindling funds and the approaching rainy season were a problem.
text: Officials Say Ebola Cases Are Falling In West Africa  Officials said that there had been a substantial reduction in new cases, but that dwindling funds and the approaching rainy season were a problem. World Health Organization says number of people becoming infected with Ebola virus in West Africa has fallen to lowest level in months; warns, however, that lack of funding and approach of rainy season may stymie efforts to control disease.

abstract: World Health Organization reports that 15 serious cases of H7N9 avian flu in humans have been confirmed by Chinese authorities, with three patients dying and the rest in critical condition.
headline: China: W.H.O. Reports 3 Deaths Among Bird Flu Cases in Humans
paragraph: The deaths were among serious cases of H7N9 avian flu in humans confirmed by China, the World Health Organization reported Monday.
text: China: W.H.O. Reports 3 Deaths Among Bird Flu Cases in Humans The deaths were among serious cases of H7N9 avian flu in humans confirmed by China, the World Health Organization reported Monday. World Health Organization reports that 15 serious cases of H7N9 avian flu in humans have been confirmed by Chinese authorities, with three patients dying and the rest in critical condition.

headline: Canada: Residents Tests Positive for H7N9 Bird Flu After Trip to China
paragraph: A resident of British Columbia has tested positive for the H7N9 avian flu virus in the first documented case of the infection in a human in North America, the federal government said Monday.
text: Canada: Residents Tests Positive for H7N9 Bird Flu After Trip to China A resident of British Columbia has tested positive for the H7N9 avian flu virus in the first documented case of the infection in a human in North America, the federal government said Monday.

abstract: Coalition of some of America's largest health care systems and insurers pledges to fundamentally alter how hospitals and doctors are paid; shift would place far less emphasis on quantity of delivered care, focusing instead on improving quality and lowering costs; plans are in line with changes signaled by Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia M Burwell.
headline: Industry Group to Back Results-Focused Care
paragraph: The new coalition said it is committed to finding a way to change financial incentives, moving the bulk of payments to so-called “value-based” arrangements by 2020.
text: Industry Group to Back Results-Focused Care The new coalition said it is committed to finding a way to change financial incentives, moving the bulk of payments to so-called “value-based” arrangements by 2020. Coalition of some of America's largest health care systems and insurers pledges to fundamentally alter how hospitals and doctors are paid; shift would place far less emphasis on quantity of delivered care, focusing instead on improving quality and lowering costs; plans are in line with changes signaled by Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia M Burwell.

abstract: World Health Organization, responding to criticism of slow and ineffective action on Ebola epidemic, backs changes to fortify its emergency response to outbreaks and other health crises.
headline: W.H.O. Members Endorse Resolution to Improve Response to Health Emergencies
paragraph: Key provisions include creating a global cadre of emergency health workers, establishing a fund that could be tapped quickly, and support for the development of treatments for emerging infectious diseases.
text: W.H.O. Members Endorse Resolution to Improve Response to Health Emergencies Key provisions include creating a global cadre of emergency health workers, establishing a fund that could be tapped quickly, and support for the development of treatments for emerging infectious diseases. World Health Organization, responding to criticism of slow and ineffective action on Ebola epidemic, backs changes to fortify its emergency response to outbreaks and other health crises.

abstract: Nigerian health and veterinary authorities report outbreaks of avian flu in both southern and northern ends of the country.
headline: Nigeria: 2 Regions Report New Outbreaks of Bird Flu
paragraph: The health and veterinary authorities on Friday reported outbreaks of avian flu hundreds of miles apart on opposite ends of Nigeria.
text: Nigeria: 2 Regions Report New Outbreaks of Bird Flu The health and veterinary authorities on Friday reported outbreaks of avian flu hundreds of miles apart on opposite ends of Nigeria. Nigerian health and veterinary authorities report outbreaks of avian flu in both southern and northern ends of the country.

abstract: World Health Organization appoints Dr Matshidiso Moeti as regional director for Africa; Moeti says she is committed to reforming office, which has long been viewed as ineffective, criticism that was validated by slow response to Ebola outbreak in West Africa.
headline: Botswana Doctor Is Named to Lead W.H.O. in Africa
paragraph: The much-praised appointee, Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, promised to overhaul the regional office, which has faced criticism for its slow response to the Ebola crisis.
text: Botswana Doctor Is Named to Lead W.H.O. in Africa The much-praised appointee, Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, promised to overhaul the regional office, which has faced criticism for its slow response to the Ebola crisis. World Health Organization appoints Dr Matshidiso Moeti as regional director for Africa; Moeti says she is committed to reforming office, which has long been viewed as ineffective, criticism that was validated by slow response to Ebola outbreak in West Africa.

abstract: Only small amounts of experimental drug ZMapp have been produced to treat Ebola virus; federal officials, researchers and biotechnology executives say attempts to procure more of drug have run into problems and delays; Department of Health and Human Services has asked for proposals to increase production, but no contracts have been awarded.
headline: Fast Track on Drug for Ebola Has Faltered
paragraph: Federal officials vowed to make more of an experimental drug that showed promise in treating Ebola, but that project has moved slowly.
text: Fast Track on Drug for Ebola Has Faltered Federal officials vowed to make more of an experimental drug that showed promise in treating Ebola, but that project has moved slowly. Only small amounts of experimental drug ZMapp have been produced to treat Ebola virus; federal officials, researchers and biotechnology executives say attempts to procure more of drug have run into problems and delays; Department of Health and Human Services has asked for proposals to increase production, but no contracts have been awarded.

abstract: Obama administration reports 9.5 million people have signed up for health care coverage through public marketplaces in 2015; White House expects a surge of enrollments just before Affordable Care Act enrollment deadline on Feb 15.
headline: Health Care Enrollment Appears to Be Near Goal
paragraph: As a Feb. 15 deadline approaches, the Obama administration said 9.5 million people had signed up for insurance this year through public marketplaces set up under the Affordable Care Act.
text: Health Care Enrollment Appears to Be Near Goal As a Feb. 15 deadline approaches, the Obama administration said 9.5 million people had signed up for insurance this year through public marketplaces set up under the Affordable Care Act. abstract: Chirlane McCray, wife of Mayor Bill de Blasio, unveils plans for a comprehensive review of mental health in New York City that will be conducted by city's health department and partners; reveals her own family's extensive struggle with mental illness to frame issue.
headline: New York City’s First Lady Shares Family History as She Unveils Push on Mental Health Care
paragraph: After describing her experiences with loved ones’ mental illnesses, Chirlane McCray announced plans for a review of the problems affecting New Yorkers to help the city address their care.

abstract: Pres Obama plans to request hundreds of millions of dollars to fund research into medical treatments attuned to specific patients' DNA and other characteristics; some experts consider so-called 'personalized medicine' or 'individualized medicine' to be forefront of field.
headline: Obama to Request Research Funding for Treatments Tailored to Patients’ DNA
paragraph: President Obama’s budget will seek hundreds of millions of dollars for “personalized medicine,” a proposal that is expected to receive bipartisan support in Congress.

abstract: T M Luhrmann Op-Ed article highlights British Psychological Society report about symptoms of mental illness that dovetails with change to how National Institute of Mental Health is approaching mental disorders; observes that both approaches suggest that mental illnesses should be treated with social interventions, not just drugs.

abstract: Editorial criticizes Congressional Republicans for their continuing attempts to weaken Affordable Care Act, most recent of which is bill that would encourage many employers to cease offering coverage to their employees; notes that measure, called Save American Workers Act, has some bipartisan support, making it a threat; warns that Pres Obama may not be able to veto bill if it is attached to other important legislation.
headline: Continued Assaults on Health Reform
paragraph: Republicans in Congress are trying to dismantle the Affordable Care Act piece by piece.
text: Continued Assaults on Health Reform  Republicans in Congress are trying to dismantle the Affordable Care Act piece by piece. Editorial criticizes Congressional Republicans for their continuing attempts to weaken Affordable Care Act, most recent of which is bill that would encourage many employers to cease offering coverage to their employees; notes that measure, called Save American Workers Act, has some bipartisan support, making it a threat; warns that Pres Obama may not be able to veto bill if it is attached to other important legislation.

abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger reviews book America's Bitter Pill: Money, Politics, Backroom Deals, and the Fight to Fix Our Broken Healthcare System by Steven Brill.

paragraph: Steven Brill has written a comprehensive chronicle of the politicking behind the Affordable Care Act, spiced by personal insights stemming from his own surgery.

headline: Obama Administration on Track to Surpass Health Care Goal
paragraph: Some 9.5 million people have already signed up for 2015 coverage under President Barack Obama's health care law, and the administration is on track to surpass its nationwide enrollment target set last year.

headline: Republicans: House to Begin Work on Health Care Alternative
paragraph: The House will vote next week to repeal the health care law Republicans have vowed to undo. They'll also direct work to start on a replacement bill the GOP promised more than four years ago.
text: Republicans: House to Begin Work on Health Care Alternative The House will vote next week to repeal the health care law Republicans have vowed to undo. They'll also direct work to start on a replacement bill the GOP promised more than four years ago.

abstract: Congressional Budget Office lowers estimated federal cost of giving health insurance coverage to Americans under Affordable Care Act to $571 billion from 2015 through 2019, down 20 percent from earlier estimate of $710 billion; says change is due to many factors, including slowing rise of health care costs.
headline: Budget Office Slashes Estimated Cost of Health Coverage
paragraph: Changes to the predicted price tag for coverage under the Affordable Care Act resulted from many factors, including a general “slowdown in the growth of health care costs.”

abstract: Former NantHealth executives Stephanie Davidson and William Lynch file lawsuit against the health technology firm alleging that it made false claims about the reliability of some of its system; accusations are part of wrongful-termination suit.
headline: Ex-Employees Accuse Health Firm of Fraud
paragraph: Two former executives of NantHealth said that the company made fraudulent claims about the reliability of its system, and may have used company donations to attract federal funds so a hospital could buy its products.

headline: California Declares Electronic Cigarettes a Health Threat
paragraph: California health officials Wednesday declared electronic cigarettes a health threat that should be strictly regulated like tobacco products, joining other states and health advocates across the U.S. in seeking tighter controls as "vaping" grows in popularity.
text: California Declares Electronic Cigarettes a Health Threat California health officials Wednesday declared electronic cigarettes a health threat that should be strictly regulated like tobacco products, joining other states and health advocates across the U.S. in seeking tighter controls as "vaping" grows in popularity.

headline: True Grits

abstract: Beverage industry is rolling out a number of new products for health-conscious drinkers, including several gluten-free, low-calorie and low-alcohol options; trend follows growing discrimination among consumers, and is particularly aimed at capturing loyalty of female drinkers; new brands include Kombrucha, mixture of tea and beer that is sweetened with agave.
headline: From Gluten-Free Beer to Kombucha, Alcohol Options for Health-Conscious Drinkers
paragraph: The American beverage industry has introduced a number of new offerings catering to consumers, especially women, who want wholesome, low-alcohol choices.
text: From Gluten-Free Beer to Kombucha, Alcohol Options for Health-Conscious Drinkers The American beverage industry has introduced a number of new offerings catering to consumers, especially women, who want wholesome, low-alcohol choices. Beverage industry is rolling out a number of new products for health-conscious drinkers, including several gluten-free, low-calorie and low-alcohol options; trend follows growing discrimination among consumers, and is particularly aimed at capturing loyalty of female drinkers; new brands include Kombrucha, mixture of tea and beer that is sweetened with agave.

abstract: University of Cincinnati men's basketball coach Mick Cronin has been staying away from games and practices after being diagnosed with arterial dissection in his brain; university says he will be back next season, but Cronin hopes that he will be well enough to return sooner if team plays in postseason.
headline: After Health Scare, Bearcats Coach Yearns for the Sideline
paragraph: Cincinnati’s Mick Cronin was told last month that he had an arterial dissection in his brain, but he hopes to return by the postseason.
text: After Health Scare, Bearcats Coach Yearns for the Sideline  Cincinnati’s Mick Cronin was told last month that he had an arterial dissection in his brain, but he hopes to return by the postseason. University of Cincinnati men's basketball coach Mick Cronin has been staying away from games and practices after being diagnosed with arterial dissection in his brain; university says he will be back next season, but Cronin hopes that he will be well enough to return sooner if team plays in postseason.

headline: Issue on Appeal: Did Health-Care Reform Rules Hurt Senator?

headline: Poll: Most Say Restore Health Aid if Court Kills Subsidies
paragraph: Most Americans including significant numbers of Republicans would want lawmakers to restore federal aid for buying coverage under President Barack Obama's health care law if the Supreme Court annuls some of the subsidies, according to a poll released Wednesday.
text: Poll: Most Say Restore Health Aid if Court Kills Subsidies Most Americans including significant numbers of Republicans would want lawmakers to restore federal aid for buying coverage under President Barack Obama's health care law if the Supreme Court annuls some of the subsidies, according to a poll released Wednesday.

abstract: Supreme Court rules chemical company M&G Polymers USA can cut health benefits of its retired union employees, reversing appeals court judgement.

paragraph: The unanimous decision reversed a lower-court ruling that found the benefits had vested for life.

headline: Panel Unanimously OKs Bill Easing Employee Health Care Count
paragraph: In a rare show of bipartisanship over President Barack Obama's health care law, a Senate committee voted unanimously Wednesday to exclude veterans from the 50-worker threshold that triggers required coverage for employees under that statute.
text: Panel Unanimously OKs Bill Easing Employee Health Care Count In a rare show of bipartisanship over President Barack Obama's health care law, a Senate committee voted unanimously Wednesday to exclude veterans from the 50-worker threshold that triggers required coverage for employees under that statute.

headline: Health Worker Exposed to Ebola Released From Omaha Hospital

headline: New Sri Lankan Health Minister Vows to Help Kidney Patients

headline: Wife of Flogged Saudi Blogger Says His Health Is Worsening
paragraph: The wife of a Saudi rights activist, sentenced last year to 1,000 lashes for criticizing the Kingdom's clerics in his blog, said on Thursday her husband's health had worsened after the first round of flogging and that he could not survive the full punishment.

headline: Privacy Concerns Over Health Care Website Prompt Reversal

headline: EU Health Chief Says No Clear Majority Yet for U.S. Trade Deal
paragraph: No clear majority has so far emerged among EU states for a free-trade agreement between the European Union and the United States and both sides need to explain the benefits of such a deal, the EU's health chief said.
text: EU Health Chief Says No Clear Majority Yet for U.S. Trade Deal No clear majority has so far emerged among EU states for a free-trade agreement between the European Union and the United States and both sides need to explain the benefits of such a deal, the EU's health chief said.

headline: Cuban Health Worker in Africa to Fight Ebola Dies of Malaria

headline: Medicare Chief Steps Down, Ran Health Care Rollout

abstract: Colorado's health insurance exchange has big disparity in premium prices, highlighting volatility of health plans under Affordable Care Act; some insurers are experimenting with very low prices that might not be sustainable over several years, while residents in state's resort areas pay relatively high premiums.
headline: In Colorado, Disparity in Health Plan Prices Underscores Ambitions, and Limits, of Affordable Care Act
paragraph: At first glance, Colorado seems to be one of the federal law’s clearest success stories. But zoom in closer, and it is clear that a kind of pricing pandemonium is underway.
text: In Colorado, Disparity in Health Plan Prices Underscores Ambitions, and Limits, of Affordable Care Act   At first glance, Colorado seems to be one of the federal law’s clearest success stories. But zoom in closer, and it is clear that a kind of pricing pandemonium is underway. Colorado's health insurance exchange has big disparity in premium prices, highlighting volatility of health plans under Affordable Care Act; some insurers are experimenting with very low prices that might not be sustainable over several years, while residents in state's resort areas pay relatively high premiums.

abstract: Food and Drug Admin opens investigation into case in which hundreds of dummy intravenous saline solution bags were given to real patients; bags of unsterilized solution, intended for use in training health care workers, have lead to one death and at least 17 cases of illness; investigation follows decision by manufacturer Wallcur to recall the bags.
headline: F.D.A. Begins Inquiry After Death and Illnesses From Saline Bags Meant for Training

abstract: Harvard researchers publish study in The New England Journal of Medicine that shows that quarter of plans on new health care exchanges may be putting HIV and AIDS drugs in tier that requires patients to pay at least 30 percent of drug's cost; practice makes drugs too expensive for many patients, and is illegal under health care reform law.

abstract: Obama administration, in unprecedented move, agrees to allow Indiana Gov Mike Pence to expand Medicaid in state to include mandate of monthly premiums for those above poverty level of 2 percent of their household incomes; additional 350,000 residents will be covered under plan, which also features penalties for non-payment.

paragraph: After a lengthy back-and-forth, the Obama administration has agreed to let Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, a Republican, expand Medicaid on his own terms, including some that have not been allowed before under federal rules.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIKAINEN, A. HELEN
paragraph:
MARTIKAINEN--Dr. A.

Helen. Of Chapel Hill, NC, age 98, died on January 16, 2015 at Carol Woods Retirement Community. Born and raised in Harrison, ME she was the daughter of the late Sylvester and Emma Martikainen. She graduated from Bridgton Academy, and received her B.A. degree from Bates College, and received post graduate degrees in public health from Yale and Harvard. Dr. Martikainen served as health education specialist with the Public Health Society Hartford, CT and several years with United States Public Health Service, Washington, DC. During service with USPHS, she was assigned to Oklahoma, and an extended assignment as Acting Director Health Education with North Carolina Board Public Health, Raleigh, NC. In 1949, Dr. Martikainen was appointed first Chief of Health Education, Headquarters, World Health Organization (WHO), Geneva, Switzerland (1949-1974). She assisted national health programs in countries worldwide. Retirement in Chapel Hill in 1978, she volunteered with N.C. Division American Association of University Women, United Nations Association of USA, N.C. Coalition of Aging, Women's Issues, Episcopal Diocese of N.C. She was a member of Women's Forum of N.C., Board of Directors for N.C. Center of Laws Affecting Women, Board of Orange County Women's Center, Advisory Board UNC School of Public Health, NC Association of Public Health and Public Health Alumni of Harvard University. At Carol Woods, she served as Chair, Residents Committee for Health; member of Residents Council, Chapel of Cross, Center of Public Policy Research. Her awards include: honorary doctorate degrees of science from Bates College and Smith College; International Award, American Public Health Assoc.; Elijah Benjamin Mays Award, Bates College; Women of Distinction Award, NC Council; special medal from National Academy of Medicine, France; Honorary Trustee Hall of Fame Bridgton Academy; election to Phi Beta Kappa, Bates College; Delta Omega Chapter, Yale University, Listed in WHO'S WHO: American Women, World Health Care & Medicine. She was predeceased by brothers, Reino J. Martikainen and Ernest W. Martikainen and sister Irja M. Bownes. She is survived by a sister, Sylvia M. Martin, sister-in-law, Mrs. Ernest W. (Priscilla) Martikainen and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, memorials made to: The Chapel of The Cross, 304 E. Franklin St., Chapel Hill, NC 27514.

headline: University of California On-Campus Doctors Stage Rare Strike

headline: Connecticut School Gunman to Be Named Only Once in Final Report

text: Oxfam Study Finds Richest 1% Is Likely to Control Half of Global Wealth by 2016 A report by the charity Oxfam offers a warning about deepening global inequality ahead of this week’s annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Oxfam releases study finding that world's richest 1 percent are set to control more than half of all global wealth by 2016, marking watershed in rise of income inequality; report, which comes days before annual World Economic Forum meeting, indicates that divide is starker than at any point in recent history.

headline: Obama Calls for Major New Personalized Medicine Initiative

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAVITZ, ANNIE
paragraph:
RAVITZ--Annie.

Annie Ravitz passed away on January 26, 2015 in her 49th year. There have been few people as brave and loving as Annie. Her beauty, unique voice and strength were a joy to all who loved her. Annie was stricken with Lupus when she only 11, and it ravaged her body for the rest of her life. Despite this she graduated high school and college on time, and even spent a semester in London at a home without a telephone. Annie went onto a career as an assistant to a New York City Councilman, then worked in children's theater and TV. Her love of the theater pervaded her whole life. All of this was accomplished in the face of constant health problems. She never gave up. Annie is survived by her father, Robert, devoted brother John, sister-in-law Berry and nephews Jack, Harry and Luke and niece Ava. She loved them all. Her mother Francine predeceased Annie. Their bond was incomparably loving. The family thanks Patricia Smith for her loving care of Annie. The funeral will be private. There will be a celebration of Annie's life on February 12th from 6pm to 9pm at the Lotus Club, 5 East 66th Street. Donations in Annie's memory may be made to the Lupus Research Institute, 330 Seventh Avenue, Suite 1701, New York, NY 10001.

headline: Cleanup Underway for Nearly 3M-Gallon Saltwater Spill in ND

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, MARILYN K.
paragraph: FENTON--Marilyn K.,passed away on January 22, 2015, at the age of 88, surrounded by her family. A graduate of Wellesley College, Lynn was a pioneer in women's health issues and spent much of her life dedicated to Planned Parenthood. She was a woman of grace and elegance, deeply engaged in the world around her until the time of her death. Lynn made you feel like the most important person in the room. She was enlightened and progressive, fiercely independent and resilient. But what most defined her was her extraordinary commitment to the love of her life and her family. Married for 60 years, Lynn and the late Dr. Arnold Fenton left a beautiful legacy of children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. She was adored by her nine grandchildren for whom she was a model of strength, intelligence, beauty and resolve. With much love, her family raises a glass of vodka with a slice of orange, and an extra glass of ice. Donations may be made in her memory to Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, New York. 1/3

Their bond was incomparably loving. The family thanks Patricia Smith for her loving care of Annie. The funeral will be private. There will be a celebration of Annie's life on February 12th from 6pm to 9pm at the Lotus Club, 5 East 66th Street. Donations in Annie's memory may be made to the Lupus Research Institute, 330 Seventh Avenue, Suite 1701, New York, NY 10001. 1/3

headline: Nearly 3M Gallons of Brine Spill; ND Oil Boom's Largest Leak
paragraph: Nearly 3 million gallons of saltwater generated by oil drilling have leaked from a North Dakota pipeline, an official said Wednesday, the largest such spill since the state's current oil boom began and nearly three times worse than previous record spills. Two creeks have been affected, but the full environmental effect might not be clear for months.

Two creeks have been affected, but the full environmental effect might not be clear for months.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, MARILYN
paragraph: FENTON--Marilyn K., passed away on January 22, 2015, at the age of 88, surrounded by her family. A graduate of Wellesley College, Lynn was a pioneer in women's health issues and spent much of her life dedicated to Planned Parenthood. She was a woman of grace and elegance, deeply engaged in the world around her until the time of her death. Lynn made you feel like the most important person in the room. She was enlightened and progressive, fiercely independent and resilient. But what most defined her was her extraordinary commitment to the love of her life and her family. Married for 60 years, Lynn and the late Dr. Arnold Fenton left a beautiful legacy of children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. She was adored by her nine grandchildren for whom she was a model of strength, intelligence, beauty and resolve. With much love, her family raises a glass of vodka with a slice of orange, and an extra glass of ice. Donations may be made in her memory to Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, New York.

She was enlightened and progressive, fiercely independent and resilient. But what most defined her was her extraordinary commitment to the love of her life and her family. Married for 60 years, Lynn and the late Dr. Arnold Fenton left a beautiful legacy of children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. headline: FACT CHECK: Obama Claims Credit for an Incomplete Recovery
paragraph: The U.S. may not have "risen from recession" quite as rousingly as President Barack Obama suggested in his State of the Union speech Tuesday night. Seven years after that severe downturn began, household income hasn't recovered and healthy job growth is complicated by the poor quality, and pay, of many of those jobs.

text: AP Analysis: Youth Concussion Laws Pushed by NFL Lack Bite Criticized for its own handling of head injuries, the NFL launched an extensive lobbying campaign to pass laws protecting kids who get concussions while playing sports. The result: Within just five years, every state had a law on the books.

headline: UK Households' Optimism Over Finances Highest on Record-Markit
paragraph: Optimism among British households about their financial prospects in the year ahead jumped to a new high this month as inflation tumbled and the prospect of higher interest rates looked more distant, a monthly survey showed on Wednesday.
text: UK Households' Optimism Over Finances Highest on Record-Markit Optimism among British households about their financial prospects in the year ahead jumped to a new high this month as inflation tumbled and the prospect of higher interest rates looked more distant, a monthly survey showed on Wednesday.

headline: Ice May Delay Restart of Pipeline's Breached Montana Section
paragraph: A ruptured section of a pipeline that spilled 1,200 barrels of Bakken crude oil is under a frozen part of the Yellowstone River in eastern Montana, which may delay an investigation that is required for the pipeline's restart.
text: Ice May Delay Restart of Pipeline's Breached Montana Section A ruptured section of a pipeline that spilled 1,200 barrels of Bakken crude oil is under a frozen part of the Yellowstone River in eastern Montana, which may delay an investigation that is required for the pipeline's restart.

headline: Puerto Rico Militant Sentenced in Record Heist Arrives Home
paragraph: Supporters of Puerto Rican independence welcomed a 69-year-old islander home Thursday after serving jail time for his role in the 1983 holdup of a Wells Fargo depot in Connecticut that netted his militant group $7 million — the largest heist in U.S. history at the time.
text: Puerto Rico Militant Sentenced in Record Heist Arrives Home Supporters of Puerto Rican independence welcomed a 69-year-old islander home Thursday after serving jail time for his role in the 1983 holdup of a Wells Fargo depot in Connecticut that netted his militant group $7 million — the largest heist in U.S. history at the time.

headline: Philips' Net Profit Slumps in 4th Quarter, Sales Edge Lower
paragraph: Royal Philips NV, the world's biggest lighting maker, said Tuesday that its net profit slumped in 2014's fourth quarter to 134 million euros ($ 151 million) from 412 million euros a year due to declining sales and restructuring costs.
text: Philips' Net Profit Slumps in 4th Quarter, Sales Edge Lower Royal Philips NV, the world's biggest lighting maker, said Tuesday that its net profit slumped in 2014's fourth quarter to 134 million euros ($ 151 million) from 412 million euros a year due to declining sales and restructuring costs.

headline: Ex-Soccer Player Offers Warning to Effects of Concussions
paragraph: Cindy Parlow Cone's first major concussion came in 2001 after a collision with a teammate left her out cold before she hit the ground. She regained consciousness, got up and continued to play but, more than a decade later, the 36-year-old Parlow Cone still deals with the symptoms of what she estimates were dozens of concussions she suffered through during her career.

headline: Myanmar's Monk Stands by Offensive Language Against UN Envoy
paragraph: Following a stinging rebuke by the United Nations' human rights chief, Myanmar's ultranationalist Buddhist monk fired back Thursday, saying he didn't regret calling a U.N. special envoy a "whore" and a "bitch" after she criticized a bill opposed to interfaith marriage and religious conversions.
text: Myanmar's Monk Stands by Offensive Language Against UN Envoy Following a stinging rebuke by the United Nations' human rights chief, Myanmar's ultranationalist Buddhist monk fired back Thursday, saying he didn't regret calling a U.N. special envoy a "whore" and a "bitch" after she criticized a bill opposed to interfaith marriage and religious conversions.

text: Daily Report: Google Makes a Big Bet on SpaceX   Google has teamed up with Fidelity to invest in SpaceX, the rocketry company founded by Elon Musk, in part to further Google’s goal of extending the Internet’s reach through satellites.

headline: Madagascar's Economy Shows Signs of Recovery, Needs Reforms-IMF
paragraph: Madagascar's economy showed early signs of recovery in 2014 with growth estimated at 3 percent, which could rise to 5 percent in 2015, but political instability, weak institutions and weak governance are hurting prospects, the IMF said.
text: Madagascar's Economy Shows Signs of Recovery, Needs Reforms-IMF Madagascar's economy showed early signs of recovery in 2014 with growth estimated at 3 percent, which could rise to 5 percent in 2015, but political instability, weak institutions and weak governance are hurting prospects, the IMF said.

headline: FBI Raids Crematorium, Body Donation Center in Illinois
paragraph: A three-day FBI raid of a suburban Chicago crematorium and an affiliated company that arranges the donation of human remains was wrapping up Thursday, authorities said, but they refused to disclose what led to the search or what evidence was seized.
text: FBI Raids Crematorium, Body Donation Center in Illinois A three-day FBI raid of a suburban Chicago crematorium and an affiliated company that arranges the donation of human remains was wrapping up Thursday, authorities said, but they refused to disclose what led to the search or what evidence was seized.

headline: Flu Hospitalizations of Elderly Hit Record High, CDC Says
paragraph: Some new evidence this is a particularly bad flu season: Flu-related hospitalizations of the elderly are the highest since the government started tracking that statistic nine years ago.
text: Flu Hospitalizations of Elderly Hit Record High, CDC Says Some new evidence this is a particularly bad flu season: Flu-related hospitalizations of the elderly are the highest since the government started tracking that statistic nine years ago.

headline: Russia Opens Fresh Case Against Ukrainian Pilot-Lawyers
paragraph: Nadezhda Savchenko, a Ukrainian army pilot under arrest in Moscow, said through her lawyers on Friday that Russia had opened a fresh case against her alleging that she had illegally crossed the border from Ukraine.
text: Russia Opens Fresh Case Against Ukrainian Pilot-Lawyers Nadezhda Savchenko, a Ukrainian army pilot under arrest in Moscow, said through her lawyers on Friday that Russia had opened a fresh case against her alleging that she had illegally crossed the border from Ukraine.

headline: Officials Say Bombings Kill 15 in Iraq's Capital, Baghdad
paragraph: A string of bombings ripped mainly through commercial areas in Iraq's capital Sunday, killing at least 15 people and wounding dozens, officials said.
text: Officials Say Bombings Kill 15 in Iraq's Capital, Baghdad A string of bombings ripped mainly through commercial areas in Iraq's capital Sunday, killing at least 15 people and wounding dozens, officials said.

headline: New Outbreak of Avian Flu Found in Washington State
paragraph: A third outbreak of avian flu has been detected in Washington state, prompting agriculture officials on Tuesday to warn bird owners to keep their flocks away from migratory birds that have spread viruses from Oregon to British Columbia.
text: New Outbreak of Avian Flu Found in Washington State A third outbreak of avian flu has been detected in Washington state, prompting agriculture officials on Tuesday to warn bird owners to keep their flocks away from migratory birds that have spread viruses from Oregon to British Columbia.

headline: Former JP Morgan Dealmakers Launch 'Friendly' Activist Fund
paragraph: Two former JP Morgan Chase & Co dealmakers said on Tuesday they had launched an activist fund that aims to work collaboratively with the boards of companies it invests in, rather than confront them as most hedge funds do.
text: Former JP Morgan Dealmakers Launch 'Friendly' Activist Fund Two former JP Morgan Chase & Co dealmakers said on Tuesday they had launched an activist fund that aims to work collaboratively with the boards of companies it invests in, rather than confront them as most hedge funds do.

headline: Leading Irish Politician Becomes First Openly Gay Minister
paragraph: One of Ireland's most prominent politicians became the first minister to announce he is gay, four months before a referendum on whether to allow same-sex marriage in the traditionally conservative Catholic country.
text: Leading Irish Politician Becomes First Openly Gay Minister One of Ireland's most prominent politicians became the first minister to announce he is gay, four months before a referendum on whether to allow same-sex marriage in the traditionally conservative Catholic country.

headline: Drugmaker AbbVie Beats Estimates as Humira Sales Rise

headline: Liberia: Only 5 People Being Treated for Ebola in Country
paragraph: Liberia said Monday that there are currently only five confirmed cases of Ebola in the entire country — a dramatic turnaround in the West African nation where the virus has taken its deadliest toll.
text: Liberia: Only 5 People Being Treated for Ebola in Country Liberia said Monday that there are currently only five confirmed cases of Ebola in the entire country — a dramatic turnaround in the West African nation where the virus has taken its deadliest toll.

headline: Haiti Minister at U.N. Asks World to Support New Government
paragraph: Haiti's foreign minister on Monday asked the U.N. Security Council and the rest of the world to continue supporting the impoverished Caribbean nation after President Michel Martelly named a new cabinet to end street protests.
text: Haiti Minister at U.N. Asks World to Support New Government Haiti's foreign minister on Monday asked the U.N. Security Council and the rest of the world to continue supporting the impoverished Caribbean nation after President Michel Martelly named a new cabinet to end street protests.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFFMAN, JOEL
paragraph:
KAUFFMAN--Joel M., PhD.

78, retired chemistry professor from the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia, researcher, consultant, and medical writer died at Paoli Hospital on January 5, 2015 of natural causes. Born in Philadelphia on January 3, 1937, son of the late David and Mathilde (Goldstein) Kauffman and predeceased by his sister Melanie, he leaves his wife of eight years Frances Heckert Pane, her daughter Natalia Pane Tyrka and grandchildren, his sister Ellen Navin, nephews Jason Levy, David O'Connor, and niece Corrine O'Connor. He received a B.S. in Chemistry from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science (now USP) and a PhD in Organic Chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He worked in the Boston area for 11 years in the chemical industry including four years at the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences. In 1979 he returned to the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia where he rose to professor, retiring after 23 years. Author of 80 papers covering chemical and medical research, he has 11 patents on potential immunogenetic anticancer drugs, antituberculosis drugs, design of radiation-hard fluors, development of oligophenylene laser dyes, and photophysical properties of proton-transfer fluors. In retirement, supported by his extensive study of existing research, he wrote "Malignant Medical Myths," an expose of the revered dogma preached by mainstream medicine. In his continuous search for the truth, Joel was skeptical of everything until proven to be correct. In retirement, he was a founding member of THINCS.org International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics.

headline: UN Chief Paints Worsening Picture of War in Syria
paragraph: Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon painted a worsening picture of the war in Syria, citing widespread conflict, indiscriminate government bombing, opposition shelling, high civilian casualties and deteriorating humanitarian conditions.
text: UN Chief Paints Worsening Picture of War in Syria Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon painted a worsening picture of the war in Syria, citing widespread conflict, indiscriminate government bombing, opposition shelling, high civilian casualties and deteriorating humanitarian conditions.

headline: Nestle Plans to Invest $138 Million in Egypt in Next Few Years

abstract: Scientists and public health experts are alarmed at practice of using insecticide-treated mosquito nets for fishing across Africa; nets, which have been widely hailed as contributing to decline in malarial infections, are not being used as intended but instead in place of traditional fishing nets; malarial infections are rising due to practice, and scientists worry insecticide and fine mesh construction of nets will damage fish populations.
headline: Meant to Keep Malaria Out, Mosquito Nets Are Used to Haul Fish In
paragraph: The nets, with holes smaller than mosquitoes, trap much more than traditional fishing nets do and could wipe out stressed fish populations in Africa.

headline: Questions and Answers About Sri Lanka Mystery Kidney Disease
paragraph: A mystery kidney disease is killing Sri Lankan farmers. The first cases surfaced some two decades ago in the country's North Central province, the main rice-producing area. Since then, the disease has killed up to an estimated 20,000 people on the Indian Ocean island nation. As researchers work to unravel the cause, and doctors continue to diagnose new patients, here are a few questions and answers about the illness.
text: Questions and Answers About Sri Lanka Mystery Kidney Disease A mystery kidney disease is killing Sri Lankan farmers. As researchers work to unravel the cause, and doctors continue to diagnose new patients, here are a few questions and answers about the illness.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHBERG, HERBERT
paragraph: GERSHBERG--Herbert, medical educator, died peacefully on January 11, 2015. Born In New York, December 1, 1917, son of Abraham and Rose Gershberg, he is survived by Beatrice, his beloved wife of 46 years and daughters Viviane, Denise and Danielle, son-in-law and best friend Ernst, grandchildren Christina, Victoria, Leah, Taylor and Corey. He got a BS from CCNY and a MS in Zoology from University Maryland. At the age of 23, he received his physician's License for New York and Connecticut and then interned in medicine at the Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. During WWII (1942-45), he was Captain AUS of the 39th Evacuation Hospital in France and Germany. Dr. Gershberg was decorated with a Bronze Star Medal, six Campaign Medals and the Meritorious Service Unit Plaque. After the war he did his fellowship in physiology, chemistry and medicine at the Yale Medical School, New Haven, CT and a fellowship at the NYU School of Medicine, where he became assistant professor of medicine and physiology and then rose to associate professor of medicine at NYU. He was a Consultant in medicine and endocrinology to Hospitals, New York, the United Nations Medical Department, New York, the Human Growth Hormone Foundation, Bethesda, MD, the Office of Professional Medical Conduct of New York State Board of Health and the W.H.O. in Geneva, Switzerland. Dr. Gershberg was a visiting professor of endocrinology at Miami School of Medicine, director of endocrine and diabetes clinics and services at Bellevue Hospital and NYU Medical Center, New York and director of the N.I.H. grant School of medicine NYU. He contributed 133 articles to scientific publications and was an editorial reviewer of numerous professioanl journals including Journal Clinical Investigation and Annals Internal Medicine, Metabolism, Journal Clinical Endocrine, Journal of AMA. He was recipient of the Career Investigator award from the N.I.H. and a State Connecticut Public Service award. He was a member of the American College Physicians, Endocrine Society, Society of Experimental Biology and Medicine, American Physiology Society, American Diabetes Society, American Men Science, Alpha Omega, Alpha Medical Honor Society and Sigma Xi Science Honor Society. Dr. Gershberg appreciated all fine things in life, a gourmet meal, a piece of art, an evening at the theatre. He liked to travel, especially to Switzerland, his wife's native country and to California to visit his daughters. Even in his later years he remained inquisitive. He enjoyed gardening and learning about plants, flowers and all kinds of insects, butterflies being his favorites. He was an avid reader, he stayed up to date with politics and never tired of watching old movies. He liked to laugh and crack a joke or two. Mostly, he cherished being with his family. He'll be sorely missed. His interment with military honors will take place at Arlington Cemetery Columbarium, Washington D.C., at a future date. 1/3
text: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHBERG, HERBERT GERSHBERG--Herbert, medical educator, died peacefully on January 11, 2015. Born In New York, December 1, 1917, son of Abraham and Rose Gershberg, he is survived by Beatrice, his beloved wife of 46 years and daughters Viviane, Denise and Danielle, son-in-law and best friend Ernst, grandchildren Christina, Victoria, Leah, Taylor and Corey. He got a BS from CCNY and a MS in Zoology from University Maryland. At the age of 23, he received his physician's License for New York and Connecticut and then interned in medicine at the Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. During WWII (1942-45), he was Captain AUS of the 39th Evacuation Hospital in France and Germany. Dr. Gershberg was decorated with a Bronze Star Medal, six Campaign Medals and the Meritorious Service Unit Plaque. After the war he did his fellowship in physiology, chemistry and medicine at the Yale Medical School, New Haven, CT and a fellowship at the NYU School of Medicine, where he became assistant professor of medicine and physiology and then rose to associate professor of medicine at NYU. He was a Consultant in medicine and endocrinology to Hospitals, New York, the United Nations Medical Department, New York, the Human Growth Hormone Foundation, Bethesda, MD, the Office of Professional Medical Conduct of New York State Board of Health and the W.H.O. in Geneva, Switzerland. Dr. Gershberg was a visiting professor of endocrinology at Miami School of Medicine, director of endocrine and diabetes clinics and services at Bellevue Hospital and NYU Medical Center, New York and director of the N.I.H. grant School of medicine NYU. He contributed 133 articles to scientific publications and was an editorial reviewer of numerous professioanl journals including Journal Clinical Investigation and Annals Internal Medicine, Metabolism, Journal Clinical Endocrine, Journal of AMA. He was recipient of the Career Investigator award from the N.I.H. and a State Connecticut Public Service award. He was a member of the American College Physicians, Endocrine Society, Society of Experimental Biology and Medicine, American Physiology Society, American Diabetes Society, American Men Science, Alpha Omega, Alpha Medical Honor Society and Sigma Xi Science Honor Society. Dr. Gershberg appreciated all fine things in life, a gourmet meal, a piece of art, an evening at the theatre. He liked to travel, especially to Switzerland, his wife's native country and to California to visit his daughters. Even in his later years he remained inquisitive. He enjoyed gardening and learning about plants, flowers and all kinds of insects, butterflies being his favorites. He was an avid reader, he stayed up to date with politics and never tired of watching old movies. He liked to laugh and crack a joke or two. Mostly, he cherished being with his family. He'll be sorely missed. His interment with military honors will take place at Arlington Cemetery Columbarium, Washington D.C., at a future date. 1/3

headline: Treasure Hunter Who Found a Fortune in Gold Is Captured
paragraph: A treasure hunter accused of cheating his investors out of their share of one of the richest hauls in U.S. history — $50 million in gold bars and coins from a 19th-century shipwreck — was captured at an upscale Florida hotel after more than two years on the lam.
text: Treasure Hunter Who Found a Fortune in Gold Is Captured A treasure hunter accused of cheating his investors out of their share of one of the richest hauls in U.S. history — $50 million in gold bars and coins from a 19th-century shipwreck — was captured at an upscale Florida hotel after more than two years on the lam.

headline: Litvinenko Autopsy Was World's Most Dangerous, UK Inquiry Hears
paragraph: Pathologists examining the body of ex-KGB spy Alexander Litvinenko, poisoned with a rare radioactive isotope nine years ago in London, carried out the world's most dangerous-ever autopsy on his body, an inquiry into his killing heard on Wednesday.
text: Litvinenko Autopsy Was World's Most Dangerous, UK Inquiry Hears Pathologists examining the body of ex-KGB spy Alexander Litvinenko, poisoned with a rare radioactive isotope nine years ago in London, carried out the world's most dangerous-ever autopsy on his body, an inquiry into his killing heard on Wednesday.

headline: Monte Dei Paschi in Talks as ECB Gets Tough on Capital
paragraph: Executives from Monte dei Paschi di Siena are making a last-ditch effort to persuade the euro zone's new banking supervisor Daniele Nouy to ease her demands on the Italian lender, sources close to the matter said, as the regulator takes a more robust approach to risk.

headline: Perry's Pet Fund for Texas Startups a Goner Under Abbott
paragraph: Republican Gov. Greg Abbott began dismantling a flagship initiative of his predecessor Thursday, saying he will abolish Rick Perry's pet program that gave $200 million in taxpayer dollars to Texas startups and was beset by bankruptcies and questionable claims of success.
text: Perry's Pet Fund for Texas Startups a Goner Under Abbott Republican Gov. Greg Abbott began dismantling a flagship initiative of his predecessor Thursday, saying he will abolish Rick Perry's pet program that gave $200 million in taxpayer dollars to Texas startups and was beset by bankruptcies and questionable claims of success.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHBERG, HERBERT
paragraph:
GERSHBERG--Herbert,

medical educator, died peacefully on January 11, 2015. Born In New York, December 1, 1917, son of Abraham and Rose Gershberg, he is survived by Beatrice, his beloved wife of 46 years and daughters Viviane, Denise and Danielle, son-in-law and best friend Ernst, grandchildren Christina, Victoria, Leah, Taylor and Corey. He got a BS from CCNY and a MS in Zoology from University Maryland. At the age of 23, he received his physician's License for New York and Connecticut and then interned in medicine at the Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. During WWII (1942-45), he was Captain AUS of the 39th Evacuation Hospital in France and Germany. Dr. Gershberg was decorated with a Bronze Star Medal, six Campaign Medals and the Meritorious Service Unit Plaque. After the war he did his fellowship in physiology, chemistry and medicine at the Yale Medical School, New Haven, CT and a fellowship at the NYU School of Medicine, where he became assistant professor of medicine and physiology and then rose to associate professor of medicine at NYU. He was a Consultant in medicine and endocrinology to Hospitals, New York, the United Nations Medical Department, New York, the Human Growth Hormone Foundation, Bethesda, MD, the Office of Professional Medical Conduct of New York State Board of Health and the W.H.O. in Geneva, Switzerland. Dr. Gershberg was a visiting professor of endocrinology at Miami School of Medicine, director of endocrine and diabetes clinics and services at Bellevue Hospital and NYU Medical Center, New York and director of the N.I.H. grant School of medicine NYU. He contributed 133 articles to scientific publications and was an editorial reviewer of numerous professioanl journals including Journal Clinical Investigation and Annals Internal Medicine, Metabolism, Journal Clinical Endocrine, Journal of AMA. He was recipient of the Career Investigator award from the N.I.H. and a State Connecticut Public Service award. He was a member of the American College Physicians, Endocrine Society, Society of Experimental Biology and Medicine, American Physiology Society, American Diabetes Society, American Men Science, Alpha Omega, Alpha Medical Honor Society and Sigma Xi Science Honor Society. Dr. Gershberg appreciated all fine things in life, a gourmet meal, a piece of art, an evening at the theatre. He liked to travel, especially to Switzerland, his wife's native country and to California to visit his daughters. Even in his later years he remained inquisitive. He enjoyed gardening and learning about plants, flowers and all kinds of insects, butterflies being his favorites. He was an avid reader, he stayed up to date with politics and never tired of watching old movies. He liked to laugh and crack a joke or two. Mostly, he cherished being with his family. He'll be sorely missed. His interment with military honors will take place at Arlington Cemetery Columbarium, Washington D.C., at a future date.

headline: Brazil Official: Rio Won't Meet Olympic Water Cleanup Pledge
paragraph: Rio de Janeiro will not make good on its Olympic pledge of slashing the flow of raw sewage and garbage into the Guanabara Bay, where the 2016 games' sailing and wind surfing competitions are to be held, the state's top environmental official acknowledged Friday.

abstract: Op-Ed article by psychologist Susan Pinker notes research showing increased technology in schools has potential to widen class divide in education rather than narrow it; observes that children in poor families are often exposed to more screen time than wealthier peers and, with less supervision by overworked parents, use computers for largely noneducational purposes; holds technology alone will not fix problem, and says money for computers should be matched by teacher training.

abstract: Series of simultaneous car bombings in Sinai region of Egypt kills 26 people; attack is first such incident since Egypt's main Islamist militant group aligned itself with Islamic State, and casts doubt on government's efforts to stem insurgency.

Series of simultaneous car bombings in Sinai region of Egypt kills 26 people; attack is first such incident since Egypt's main Islamist militant group aligned itself with Islamic State, and casts doubt on government's efforts to stem insurgency.

abstract: Commerce Dept reports that orders for non-defense capital goods dropped 0.6 percent in December, far below economist expectations, as overall orders for durable goods decline by 3.4 percent; also reports rise in new-home sales and consumer confidence; data, along with several other reports, suggests mixed economic performance as falling oil prices and slow global growth weigh on United States economy.

text: Highway Reopens After Construction Collapse; 1 Dead, 1 Hurt A highway where an overpass collapse during demolition work left one worker dead and a tractor-trailer driver injured was cleared of concrete and steel on Tuesday and reopened, but police were left wondering what the casualty toll might have been had the accident occurred amid heavy traffic.

headline: China 2015 Growth to Slip Further on Weak Lending; RRR and Rate Cuts Likely
paragraph: China's economic growth rate is likely to cool further this year, restrained by sluggish lending, a housing slump and weak global demand, a Reuters poll showed.
text: China 2015 Growth to Slip Further on Weak Lending; RRR and Rate Cuts Likely China's economic growth rate is likely to cool further this year, restrained by sluggish lending, a housing slump and weak global demand, a Reuters poll showed.

headline: In South Africa, Land Apartheid Lives On
paragraph: The government's reform program is undermining instead of promoting black economic development.
text: In South Africa, Land Apartheid Lives On The government's reform program is undermining instead of promoting black economic development.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
paragraph: Television highlights.
text: What’s on TV Thursday Television highlights.

abstract: Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column reflects on life of his old high school friend Kevin Green, who has died at 54; notes that many might consider Green a moocher, as he survived on disability and food stamps; posits that Green's fate, like many other Americans, was in some part due to nation's trend toward income inequality, and to mostly ignored evidence of existing empathy gap between affluent and non-affluent Americans.
headline: Where’s the Empathy?
paragraph: My old running buddy Kevin couldn’t get a good job. Now he’s dead at age 54.
text: Where’s the Empathy? My old running buddy Kevin couldn’t get a good job. Now he’s dead at age 54. Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column reflects on life of his old high school friend Kevin Green, who has died at 54; notes that many might consider Green a moocher, as he survived on disability and food stamps; posits that Green's fate, like many other Americans, was in some part due to nation's trend toward income inequality, and to mostly ignored evidence of existing empathy gap between affluent and non-affluent Americans.

abstract: Former Florida Gov Jeb Bush, in his first public speech since announcing his exploration of presidential run, calls on political leaders to overhaul country's immigration system.
headline: Jeb Bush Sounds Sympathetic Note for Immigrants
paragraph: The speech was the first offered by Jeb Bush since he announced he was actively exploring a run for the presidency, and it focused on traditional conservative positions and avoided specifics.
text: Jeb Bush Sounds Sympathetic Note for Immigrants The speech was the first offered by Jeb Bush since he announced he was actively exploring a run for the presidency, and it focused on traditional conservative positions and avoided specifics. Former Florida Gov Jeb Bush, in his first public speech since announcing his exploration of presidential run, calls on political leaders to overhaul country's immigration system.

headline: US Stocks Rise on Expected European Stimulus, Higher Oil
paragraph: Another choppy day on Wall Street ended with stocks broadly higher on hopes of new stimulus measures for Europe's weak economy and a sharp rise in oil prices.
text: US Stocks Rise on Expected European Stimulus, Higher Oil Another choppy day on Wall Street ended with stocks broadly higher on hopes of new stimulus measures for Europe's weak economy and a sharp rise in oil prices.

headline: Column: Vonn, for Once an Athlete Truly Deserving of 'Star'
paragraph: The most overused word in sports is "star." It should be reserved only for the deserving few, those who constantly brighten our horizons with their exploits, who don't wax, wane and flame out in a season or two and, most importantly, who don't cheat, dope, act like idiots and otherwise prove that sports are too quick to build pedestals for athletes.
text: Column: Vonn, for Once an Athlete Truly Deserving of 'Star' The most overused word in sports is "star." It should be reserved only for the deserving few, those who constantly brighten our horizons with their exploits, who don't wax, wane and flame out in a season or two and, most importantly, who don't cheat, dope, act like idiots and otherwise prove that sports are too quick to build pedestals for athletes.

headline: NYC Debates: Does Airbnb Help or Hurt Affordable Housing?
paragraph: They cater to travelers, but Airbnb and other short-term rental sites are sparking debate over an issue few tourists are likely to unpack: affordable housing.
text: NYC Debates: Does Airbnb Help or Hurt Affordable Housing? They cater to travelers, but Airbnb and other short-term rental sites are sparking debate over an issue few tourists are likely to unpack: affordable housing.

headline: US Loosens Embargo on Cuba, Making Trade and Travel Easier
paragraph: The Obama administration is putting a large dent in the U.S. embargo against Cuba as of Friday, significantly loosening restrictions on American trade and investment.
text: US Loosens Embargo on Cuba, Making Trade and Travel Easier The Obama administration is putting a large dent in the U.S. embargo against Cuba as of Friday, significantly loosening restrictions on American trade and investment.

abstract: Carl Krawitt of Corte Madera, Calif, father of 6-year-old boy with leukemia, asks Reed Union School District in Marin County to keep unvacciinated children out of school due to the danger they represent to his son's medical fragility; vaccine resistance has spread among parents, and dangerous childhood diseases like measles have been making comeback.
headline: Sick Child’s Father Seeks Vaccination Requirement in California
paragraph: Carl Krawitt, of Marin County, argued that parents who refused to have their children vaccinated against diseases like measles were putting his son at risk.
text: Sick Child’s Father Seeks Vaccination Requirement in California Carl Krawitt, of Marin County, argued that parents who refused to have their children vaccinated against diseases like measles were putting his son at risk. Carl Krawitt of Corte Madera, Calif, father of 6-year-old boy with leukemia, asks Reed Union School District in Marin County to keep unvacciinated children out of school due to the danger they represent to his son's medical fragility; vaccine resistance has spread among parents, and dangerous childhood diseases like measles have been making comeback.

headline: The Surprise Isn’t That an Extreme Party Won in Greece. It’s That It Took This Long.
paragraph: The election of an anti-austerity party has been met with remarkable calm in Europe, with most European markets up.
text: The Surprise Isn’t That an Extreme Party Won in Greece. It’s That It Took This Long. The election of an anti-austerity party has been met with remarkable calm in Europe, with most European markets up.

headline: Kobe to Be Re-examined Before Deciding Injury Fate
paragraph: Kobe Bryant's torn right rotator cuff will be re-examined Monday before the Los Angeles Lakers decide whether the superstar guard needs potentially season-ending surgery.
text: Kobe to Be Re-examined Before Deciding Injury Fate Kobe Bryant's torn right rotator cuff will be re-examined Monday before the Los Angeles Lakers decide whether the superstar guard needs potentially season-ending surgery.

headline: Saudi Arabia Nears Generational Change in the Throne
paragraph: With the death of King Abdullah, the throne of Saudi Arabia passed to another son of the country's founder as it has relatively smoothly for the past six decades. But it brings the oil-rich kingdom one step closer to a question that will test the unity of its royal family: Who in the next generation will reign?
text: Saudi Arabia Nears Generational Change in the Throne With the death of King Abdullah, the throne of Saudi Arabia passed to another son of the country's founder as it has relatively smoothly for the past six decades. But it brings the oil-rich kingdom one step closer to a question that will test the unity of its royal family: Who in the next generation will reign?

headline: Small Businesses Hunker Down, Cope During Big Winter Storm
paragraph: The huge snowstorm that hit the Northeast Monday had some small companies hunkering down and others coping with a spike in business.
text: Small Businesses Hunker Down, Cope During Big Winter Storm The huge snowstorm that hit the Northeast Monday had some small companies hunkering down and others coping with a spike in business.

headline: Congo Protests Expose Weakness of Kabila's Coalition
paragraph: Protests that blocked a reform which could have extended Congo President Joseph Kabila's rule have exposed deep rifts in his ruling coalition and galvanized opposition, increasing the chance of further unrest ahead of elections due next year.
text: Congo Protests Expose Weakness of Kabila's Coalition Protests that blocked a reform which could have extended Congo President Joseph Kabila's rule have exposed deep rifts in his ruling coalition and galvanized opposition, increasing the chance of further unrest ahead of elections due next year.

headline: Millions of GMO Insects Could Be Released in Florida Keys
paragraph: Millions of genetically modified mosquitoes could be released in the Florida Keys if British researchers win approval to use the bugs against two extremely painful viral diseases.
text: Millions of GMO Insects Could Be Released in Florida Keys Millions of genetically modified mosquitoes could be released in the Florida Keys if British researchers win approval to use the bugs against two extremely painful viral diseases.

headline: Senior U.S. Diplomat Ruffles Cuba by Meeting Dissidents
paragraph: A senior U.S. diplomat in Cuba for negotiations on restoring long-frozen diplomatic relations met a group of dissidents on Friday, seeking to underline Washington's concern over human rights but irritating the island's communist government.
text: Senior U.S. Diplomat Ruffles Cuba by Meeting Dissidents A senior U.S. diplomat in Cuba for negotiations on restoring long-frozen diplomatic relations met a group of dissidents on Friday, seeking to underline Washington's concern over human rights but irritating the island's communist government.

abstract: Pres Obama, speaking at the University of Kansas, reveals $80 billion plan to shore up federal subsidies to working American families who struggle with child care; plan would nearly double aid and bring more than one million additional children into program; comments come as Obama promotes new domestic policies in Republican stronghold states.
headline: Obama Proposes Expansion of Program Providing Subsidies for Child Care
paragraph: The president called for a major investment in a federal program, the Child Care and Development Fund, which is on top of the tax credit he announced in his State of the Union address.
text: Obama Proposes Expansion of Program Providing Subsidies for Child Care The president called for a major investment in a federal program, the Child Care and Development Fund, which is on top of the tax credit he announced in his State of the Union address. Pres Obama, speaking at the University of Kansas, reveals $80 billion plan to shore up federal subsidies to working American families who struggle with child care; plan would nearly double aid and bring more than one million additional children into program; comments come as Obama promotes new domestic policies in Republican stronghold states.

headline: Wendell Ford, Ex-Kentucky Governor, US Senator, Dies at 90
paragraph: Former U.S. Sen. and Kentucky Gov. Wendell Ford, an unapologetic smoker whose unfiltered chats and speeches endeared him to voters in a state that once thrived on tobacco and coal, has died at age 90.
text: Wendell Ford, Ex-Kentucky Governor, US Senator, Dies at 90 Former U.S. Sen. and Kentucky Gov. Wendell Ford, an unapologetic smoker whose unfiltered chats and speeches endeared him to voters in a state that once thrived on tobacco and coal, has died at age 90.

abstract: Google, in partnership with Fidelity Investments, invests $1 billion in Space Exploration Technologies, private rocketry company known as SpaceX that was founded by Elon Musk; investment is in line with Google's ambition to create satellite network that could bring Internet to globe's most remote corners.
headline: Google and Fidelity Put $1 Billion Into SpaceX
paragraph: Google and Fidelity have invested in the rocketry company founded by Elon Musk, in part to further Google’s goal of extending the Internet’s reach through satellites.
text: Google and Fidelity Put $1 Billion Into SpaceX Google and Fidelity have invested in the rocketry company founded by Elon Musk, in part to further Google’s goal of extending the Internet’s reach through satellites. Google, in partnership with Fidelity Investments, invests $1 billion in Space Exploration Technologies, private rocketry company known as SpaceX that was founded by Elon Musk; investment is in line with Google's ambition to create satellite network that could bring Internet to globe's most remote corners.

headline: Once Dominant, State of Union Address Has Much Competition
paragraph: Before cable television, Netflix, YouTube and other attention-grabbers on the Internet, American presidents had little competition for viewers when they delivered their annual State of the Union address. But, oh, how the big night has changed.
text: Once Dominant, State of Union Address Has Much Competition Before cable television, Netflix, YouTube and other attention-grabbers on the Internet, American presidents had little competition for viewers when they delivered their annual State of the Union address. headline: China Unveils Fresh Support Measures as Economy Shows Renewed Weakness
paragraph: China announced fresh support measures on Friday for its slowing economy after data showed a worrying drop in bank lending and foreign investment growth falling to a two-year low.
text: China Unveils Fresh Support Measures as Economy Shows Renewed Weakness China announced fresh support measures on Friday for its slowing economy after data showed a worrying drop in bank lending and foreign investment growth falling to a two-year low.

abstract: Christina Salway and husband John Moskowitz have refurbished run-down farmhouse near Callicoon, NY.

text: With Wide-Open Acres It was easy to embrace a dilapidated farmhouse when the buyers saw the chunk of property it sat on. Christina Salway and husband John Moskowitz have refurbished run-down farmhouse near Callicoon, NY.

headline: Obama to Cut Short India Trip to Pay Call on Saudi Arabia
paragraph: President Barack Obama will shorten his trip to India and divert to Saudi Arabia, paying respects after the death of King Abdullah and meeting with the oil-rich nation's new monarch, the White House said Saturday.
text: Obama to Cut Short India Trip to Pay Call on Saudi Arabia President Barack Obama will shorten his trip to India and divert to Saudi Arabia, paying respects after the death of King Abdullah and meeting with the oil-rich nation's new monarch, the White House said Saturday.

headline: Riley Speaks on Heat Season, Insists Miami Is Playoff-Worthy

abstract: Prospect of new stimulus measures in Europe and increase in oil prices leads to shares ending broadly higher on Wall Street.

abstract: A current measles outbreak, now at 48 confirmed cases, began with a visitor to Disneyland, and quickly spread beyond those directly exposed there.

headline: Separatists Renew Attack on Airport as Russia and Ukraine Bicker
paragraph: Pro-Russian separatists renewed attacks on Ukrainian forces at an airport complex in the east on Monday after Kiev launched a mass operation to reclaim lost ground there that Russia called a "strategic mistake".
text: Separatists Renew Attack on Airport as Russia and Ukraine Bicker Pro-Russian separatists renewed attacks on Ukrainian forces at an airport complex in the east on Monday after Kiev launched a mass operation to reclaim lost ground there that Russia called a "strategic mistake".

headline: Romney, Clinton Offer Signs '16 Will Be About Economy
paragraph: Not yet in the presidential race, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mitt Romney already are previewing the likely focus of the 2016 campaign, a competition over who's better able to boost paychecks for working Americans.

headline: Egypt Blames Muslim Brotherhood for Deadly Sinai Attack
paragraph: Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi blamed the Muslim Brotherhood for playing a role in a sophisticated insurgent attack that killed 31 people in Egypt's volatile northern Sinai Peninsula. El-Sissi, a former army chief, cut short a trip to Ethiopia to return to Cairo Friday, as state television broadcast the arrival of the bodies of slain soldiers in coffins draped with Egyptian flags.

headline: Federal Government Failing to Protect Children, Report Says

abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Zephyr Teachout, in light of corruption charges against New York Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, argues kickbacks and quid pro quo are a natural outgrowth of state's campaign finance system; holds even legal contributions can exert a strong corrupting influence, and can lead to outright bribery as politicians become more calloused; calls for systemic reform, including a rejection of private campaign financing.
