abstract: Op-Ed article by Angelina Jolie declares that suffering she witnessed in camps for refugees from Syria and Iraq is worse than any she has encountered in her previous four visits to region since 2007; calls on international community to do more to help millions displaced and traumatized by conflict and war crimes committed by Islamic State group in Syria and Iraq; underscores need for peace settlement in Syria.
headline: A New Level of Refugee Suffering
paragraph: I have visited camps before, but this time the pain left me speechless.
text: A New Level of Refugee Suffering I have visited camps before, but this time the pain left me speechless. Op-Ed article by Angelina Jolie declares that suffering she witnessed in camps for refugees from Syria and Iraq is worse than any she has encountered in her previous four visits to region since 2007; calls on international community to do more to help millions displaced and traumatized by conflict and war crimes committed by Islamic State group in Syria and Iraq; underscores need for peace settlement in Syria.

abstract: Cristian Tomasetti and Bert Vogelstein study in journal Science concluding that many cancers are caused by random genetic mutations and are in essence unpreventable has triggered backlash and despair among some; accepting role of random chance in biology and humans' limited ability to control phenomena, however, can also be liberating.

headline: Radical Left Political Outsiders Prepare for Power in Greece
paragraph: Dressed in an open-collar shirt and blue suede shoes, Alexis Tsipras arrives at his party's headquarters for a live Q-and-A session on Twitter. The session is moderated by a leftwing newspaper that normally sells less than 2,000 copies a day. But Tsipras is reaching a much bigger audience: Foreign camera crews pack the tiny studio, and soon the hashtag #asktsipras is trending worldwide.

headline: Snails Slither Into Spa Scene in Thailand and Around World
paragraph: The last time I encountered escargots they were served up by a French waiter, sizzling in garlic and herb butter. Now, one is slithering up the bridge of my nose while five others are being stuck onto other parts of my face by a Thai beautician, all secreting snail slime to hopefully smooth out some wrinkles and otherwise give me a younger-than-my-age look.

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column submits events in Greece challenge Europe to move past inaccurate and moralizing views of Greece's role in euro crisis and to look at situation in more realistic and productive way; holds Greece has gained little benefit from loans and cannot afford to repay them, and that to expect repayment is to inflict endless suffering and risk country's withdrawal from euro; urges Europe to cut some losses in order to preserve greater health of system.

abstract: New York nursing homes are now routinely leveraging state's guardianship statute as they seek to force families to pay bills; law, which transfer's a person's legal rights and decision-making power to a court appointee, was originally intended to protect those who are incapable of managing their own affairs; nursing homes are now using the statute instead as a powerful debt collection tool in compelling families to pay disputed bills.

headline: Egypt: 15 Killed in Clashes Between Islamists, Police
paragraph: Anti-government protesters fought street battles with police in Cairo and other cities on Sunday, the fourth anniversary of the country's 2011 uprising, as clashes left at least 15 people dead and dozens injured. Another two people died when an explosive device they were planting under a high-voltage tower in the Nile Delta exploded prematurely, according to security officials.

abstract: Biotech industry is riding unprecedented wave of soaring stock prices and high rate of drug approvals, but executives and investors remain divided in their opinion of its future; some argue that industry has turned a corner in which high failure rate of new drugs has permanently declined, and that Big Pharma is set to take on new set of illnesses for first time; others remain skeptical, citing imminent bubble.

abstract: Argentinian Pres Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner announces that she will ask Congress to dissolve Intelligence Secretariat so it can be replaced with new agency with curtailed surveillance powers; move is response to mysterious death of prosecutor Alberto Nisman, who was conducting inquiry into 1994 attack on Jewish center; Kirchner blames rogue elements within intelligence agency for impeding agreement with Iran to jointly investigate attack.

abstract: Number of middle-class households, or those making $35,000 to $100,000 annually, continues to narrow since 2000 as more fall down the economic ladder; at same time, increasingly fewer of the 53 million households remaining in middle class, or about 43 percent of total, fit traditional image of married couple raising children.

abstract: US Meat Animal Research Center in Nebraska has re-engineered farm animals with several distinct market advantages, but changes have come at cruel cost for the animals; taxpayer-funded research has yielded less costly animals with more offspring and leaner and more plentiful meat, but many of them are born weakened and deformed, dying in huge numbers or living brief lives of intense suffering.
headline: U.S. Research Lab Lets Livestock Suffer in Quest for Profit
paragraph: In the past 50 years, meat has gotten less fatty and easier to chew — thanks in part to the U.S. Meat Animal Research Center. But the achievement has come at a steep cost to the lab’s animals.

headline: Obama Seeking Tax Increases on Wealthy to Help Middle Class

text: Why Spending Is Back in Season in Washington The deficit is down, for now, and the sense of budgetary crisis has vanished as bipartisan pressure is rising to increase spending. abstract: Israeli human rights group B'Tselem study finds attacks by Israel on homes in Gaza during 2014 war against Hamas that resulted in deaths of more than 600 Palestinians, most of them women, children and elderly, violated international law; study, first major one from an Israeli group, is released as International Criminal Court in The Hague begins inquiry into possible war crimes committed in Palestinian territories.
headline: Israeli Group Says Military Attacks on Palestinian Homes Appeared to Violate Law
paragraph: A human rights group said attacks in Gaza against Hamas last summer appeared in some cases to violate the provisions of international law, a report said.

abstract: Scientists reporting in journal Nature Medicine find most siblings with autism diagnosis have different genetic risk factors for disorder and their behaviors are as independent and varied as any brothers and sisters; study analyzed genetic material from 85 families, with 70 percent of sibling pairs not sharing same mutation.
headline: More Differences Than Similarities Are Found in Autistic Siblings
paragraph: Most siblings with a diagnosis do not share the same genetic risk factors for the disorder and are as distinct in their behaviors as any brothers and sisters, scientists reported.
text: More Differences Than Similarities Are Found in Autistic Siblings Most siblings with a diagnosis do not share the same genetic risk factors for the disorder and are as distinct in their behaviors as any brothers and sisters, scientists reported. Scientists reporting in journal Nature Medicine find most siblings with autism diagnosis have different genetic risk factors for disorder and their behaviors are as independent and varied as any brothers and sisters; study analyzed genetic material from 85 families, with 70 percent of sibling pairs not sharing same mutation.

abstract: NASA and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration release separate reports showing 2014 was hottest year on Earth since records first started being kept in 1880; data shows heat records were set over large areas of every continent except Antarctica, bolstering many scientists' warnings about risks of climate change and greenhouse gas emissions and refuting assertions by some scientists that global warming has stopped.
headline: 2014 Breaks Heat Record, Challenging Global Warming Skeptics
paragraph: Extreme land temperatures were accompanied by an unusually warm ocean surface virtually everywhere except around Antarctica, scientists reported.
text: 2014 Breaks Heat Record, Challenging Global Warming Skeptics  Extreme land temperatures were accompanied by an unusually warm ocean surface virtually everywhere except around Antarctica, scientists reported. NASA and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration release separate reports showing 2014 was hottest year on Earth since records first started being kept in 1880; data shows heat records were set over large areas of every continent except Antarctica, bolstering many scientists' warnings about risks of climate change and greenhouse gas emissions and refuting assertions by some scientists that global warming has stopped.

headline: Inquest: Sydney Café Hostage Killed by Police Bullet
paragraph: A hostage who died during a siege in a downtown Sydney cafe was killed when she was struck by fragments of a bullet fired from a police officer's gun as authorities stormed in to end the 16-hour standoff, a lawyer told an inquest on Thursday.
text: Inquest: Sydney Café Hostage Killed by Police Bullet A hostage who died during a siege in a downtown Sydney cafe was killed when she was struck by fragments of a bullet fired from a police officer's gun as authorities stormed in to end the 16-hour standoff, a lawyer told an inquest on Thursday.

headline: New Saudi King Seeks to Reassure on Succession and Policy
paragraph: Saudia Arabia's new King Salman pledged continuity in energy and foreign policies on Friday and moved quickly to appoint younger men as his heirs, settling the succession for years to come by naming a deputy crown prince from his dynasty's next generation.
text: New Saudi King Seeks to Reassure on Succession and Policy Saudia Arabia's new King Salman pledged continuity in energy and foreign policies on Friday and moved quickly to appoint younger men as his heirs, settling the succession for years to come by naming a deputy crown prince from his dynasty's next generation.

abstract: News Analysis; Thailand's military junta's legislative assembly votes overwhelmingly to impeach former Prime Min Yingluck Shinawatra, barring her from public office for five years; junta indicates Shinawatra will be indicted on charge of criminal negligence; actions threaten to prolong conflict in country and dispel junta's claim to being honest broker.
headline: In Targeting Ex-Premier, Thai Junta Takes a Risk
paragraph: The decision to prosecute Yingluck Shinawatra, who enjoys the support of the provinces, risks prolonging what has already been a lost decade of economy-sapping protests and coups.

abstract: Op-Ed article by author Tolu Ogunlesi underscores unprecedented nature of threat posed to Nigeria by Boko Haram, which is essentially army of psychopaths masquerading as Islamic proselytizers; expresses hope that Nigerians will oust Pres Goodluck Jonathan in next election over his ineffectual efforts to defeat Boko Haram.

abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that index of consumer prices rose just 0.8 percent in 2014, slowest pace of inflation during an economic recovery in the last half-century; figure represents evidence that recovery is still incomplete, and could hamper the Federal Reserve as it seeks to retreat from stimulus.
headline: Slow Rise in Consumer Prices May Stymie the Fed
paragraph: The slow pace of inflation means Americans are experiencing less erosion in the value of their paychecks at a time when wages, too, are rising slowly. But it is also evidence the recovery is incomplete.

headline: Native Hawaiians Debate Best Path to Sovereignty
paragraph: Pookela Rodenhurst lives as if he's back in the Hawaiian Kingdom. He hunts for sea turtles, watching for the game warden behind his back. He forages for herbs in the Koolau Mountains. He drives without a license because he won't agree to abide by state laws.

abstract: Jamaat-ud-Dawa, charity wing of Pakistani militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba, begins ambulance service in Karachi, in telling sign that some militant groups continue to be tolerated by government; some view unveiling of service functions as calculated display of group's ability to operate with impunity.
headline: In Pakistan, a Charity Project Points to Official Tolerance of Militants
paragraph: On Monday, Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the group that waged the deadly 2008 Mumbai attacks, inaugurated an ambulance service run by the group’s charity wing, Jamaat-ud-Dawa, in Karachi.

abstract: NFL's nonprofit arm USA Football has begun conducting nationwide Moms Clinics, workshops that teach mothers that their children can play football safely, in order to stem declining participation in youth tackle football; campaign comes as several studies show that concussions and other head injuries incurred by playing sport in childhood can lead to memory and cognitive problems later in life.
headline: To Allay Fears, N.F.L. Huddles With Mothers
paragraph: Through a nonprofit group, USA Football, the N.F.L. has tried to reassure mothers, many of whom decide which sports their children play, that football can be played safely.

abstract: Surabaya Journal; Surabaya, Indonesia, has become gathering point for families grieving relatives lost in crash of AirAsia Flight 8501, which plummeted into Java Sea, killing all 162 aboard; many families visit city's crisis centers daily in hoping to receive news of 92 victims whose bodies have not been found.
headline: After Crash of AirAsia Flight, Old Port City Has Sad New Role

abstract: European Central Bank's bond buying program, scheduled to start in March, is intended to help eurozone's 18.4 million unemployed residents, but it could have unwelcome consequences; some people, industries and countries will benefit from stimulus more than others.

headline: In France's Suburbs, State Neglect Breeds Resentment
paragraph: Soul-searching in France in the weeks since Islamist gunmen killed 17 people has centred on battling radical Islam and reinforcing the country's secular tradition. In the "cités", housing estates like those in which the gunmen grew up, this seems to many like seeking a scapegoat for decades of neglect.

headline: Jobless and Desperate, Egyptians Risk All in Perilous Libya

abstract: Basic goods and services are in short supply in Venezuela, as country lacks currency due to plunging price of oil, its biggest export; government troops patrol long lines of people waiting for supplies, and stand ready to arrest those shoppers cheating rationing system; Venezuela was in deep recession even before oil prices collapsed (Series: By the Barrel).

abstract: Researchers say a computer model can predict your personality based on your Facebook Likes, and such predictions could one day be used in hiring, banking and more. But should they?

abstract: Art patron and saloniste Peggy Cooper Cafritz has spent last five years creating new art-filled home in Washington, DC, after fire destroyed her old one.

paragraph: The Washington saloniste has not let setbacks keep her from her passion: collecting African and African-American art.
text: Peggy Cooper Cafritz: Everything in a Big Way The Washington saloniste has not let setbacks keep her from her passion: collecting African and African-American art. Art patron and saloniste Peggy Cooper Cafritz has spent last five years creating new art-filled home in Washington, DC, after fire destroyed her old one.

abstract: Roberta Smith Critic's Notebook observes that there is an unusual number of interesting and eclectic art-gallery group shows in New York City this season; offers list of her top 15 picks.

abstract: Rachelle Williams is 13-year-old diagnosed with Prader-Willi Syndrome, one of few genetic causes of obesity, and is in program at Children's Institute of Pittsburgh that teaches those with disorder how to manage it; disease has range of symptoms, most prominent of which is heightened, permanent sensation of hunger.
headline: ‘Food Is a Death Sentence to These Kids’
paragraph: Day by day, meal by meal, training children to cope with Prader-Willi syndrome, a rare genetic form of obesity.
text: ‘Food Is a Death Sentence to These Kids’ Day by day, meal by meal, training children to cope with Prader-Willi syndrome, a rare genetic form of obesity. Rachelle Williams is 13-year-old diagnosed with Prader-Willi Syndrome, one of few genetic causes of obesity, and is in program at Children's Institute of Pittsburgh that teaches those with disorder how to manage it; disease has range of symptoms, most prominent of which is heightened, permanent sensation of hunger.

abstract: Adoptee Solidarity Korea, group formed by Koreans who were given up for adoption and ended up with families overseas, most in United States, has lobbied for legislation in South Korea that has reduced flow of Korean children out of country; group's success has led to similar movements in other nations, all of them questioning concept of international adoption.
headline: Why a Generation of Adoptees Is Returning to South Korea
paragraph: A movement is raising soul-searching questions about international adoption.
text: Why a Generation of Adoptees Is Returning to South Korea A movement is raising soul-searching questions about international adoption. Adoptee Solidarity Korea, group formed by Koreans who were given up for adoption and ended up with families overseas, most in United States, has lobbied for legislation in South Korea that has reduced flow of Korean children out of country; group's success has led to similar movements in other nations, all of them questioning concept of international adoption.

abstract: Op-Ed article by Seth Stephens-Davidowitz reports on his findings about what Google search data can reveal about sexual habits; notes that in many ways Google search data is more reliable than traditional surveys due to fact that people are often not honest about their sex lives.
headline: Searching for Sex
paragraph: What big data reveals and conceals about our desires, our bodies and our many insecurities.
text: Searching for Sex What big data reveals and conceals about our desires, our bodies and our many insecurities. Op-Ed article by Seth Stephens-Davidowitz reports on his findings about what Google search data can reveal about sexual habits; notes that in many ways Google search data is more reliable than traditional surveys due to fact that people are often not honest about their sex lives.

abstract: Singer and artist Bjork has channeled multiple sides of her creative persona--solitary and collaborative, musical and visual--in her retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.
headline: The Peculiar Genius of Björk
paragraph: Solo musician or master collaborator? For her new album, Björk has merged the two sides of her artistry to create a new experience of music — again.
text: The Peculiar Genius of Björk Solo musician or master collaborator? For her new album, Björk has merged the two sides of her artistry to create a new experience of music — again. Singer and artist Bjork has channeled multiple sides of her creative persona--solitary and collaborative, musical and visual--in her retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

abstract: People close to former Florida Gov Jeb Bush, who is readying himself for 2016 presidential run, say he and brother former Pres George W Bush are supportive of each other, but not terribly close; they share conservative stance on political and social issues, but travel in different circles and have different political networks.
headline: The Bushes, as Distinct and Alike as Brothers Can Be
paragraph: While loving and supportive of each other, George W. and Jeb Bush do not talk that often, according to family intimates, and they travel in different circles.
text: The Bushes, as Distinct and Alike as Brothers Can Be While loving and supportive of each other, George W. and Jeb Bush do not talk that often, according to family intimates, and they travel in different circles. People close to former Florida Gov Jeb Bush, who is readying himself for 2016 presidential run, say he and brother former Pres George W Bush are supportive of each other, but not terribly close; they share conservative stance on political and social issues, but travel in different circles and have different political networks.

abstract: Investigation into fatal shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice finds series of miscommunications, errors and systemic failures on part of Cleveland police created unstoppable cascade of events ending with tragedy; earlier episodes of abuse by police had led Cleveland and Justice Dept to agree to carve out consent decree tightening use-of-force policies and subject city police to oversight by a monitor but many reforms were never maintained.
headline: In Tamir Rice Case, Many Errors by Cleveland Police, Then a Fatal One
paragraph: Miscommunications, tactical errors and institutional failures by the Cleveland police cascaded into one irreversible mistake: the shooting of a 12-year-old boy.
text: In Tamir Rice Case, Many Errors by Cleveland Police, Then a Fatal One Miscommunications, tactical errors and institutional failures by the Cleveland police cascaded into one irreversible mistake: the shooting of a 12-year-old boy. Investigation into fatal shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice finds series of miscommunications, errors and systemic failures on part of Cleveland police created unstoppable cascade of events ending with tragedy; earlier episodes of abuse by police had led Cleveland and Justice Dept to agree to carve out consent decree tightening use-of-force policies and subject city police to oversight by a monitor but many reforms were never maintained.
